## A more traditional definition

.content-box-red[ 
### Social revolutions are rapid, basic transformations of a society’s state and class structures … accompanied and in part carried through by class-based revolts from below. (Skocpol 1979, 4)

# The contagion (Weyland 2012): 1848 Europe and 2011 MENA

- .Large[traditional explanations (structural, ideas, external influence) fall short:]

--

  - .large[combustion `r fa("fire", fill='red')` led by one event: France  (Louis Phillip) and Tunisia (Ben Ali)]
  
--
  - .large[rapid and regionally clustered]
  
--
  - .large[subsided rather quickly]
  
--
  - .large[no strong foreign promoter]

--

- .Large[A better explanation: .pink[cognitive shortcuts] and .Green[inferential heuristics]]

--
  - .large[**psychology**: in times of profound uncertainty, norms and institutions losing legitimacy, and 'anything viewed as possible', people tend to rely on easy ways (cognitive shortcuts--dramatic events) to 'get a minimal grip' (Weyland 2012, 921), even though that might be .green[irrational].]
  
--
  - .large[the .red[fall] of a well-known regional leader: a cognitive shortcut `r fa("arrow-right", fill='blue')` a rush to emulating effort, .orange[discounting] local conditions]
  
--
  - .large[a compounding factor: lack of .red[social organizations]]
